conclusion: To solve the problem of finding the electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square, we need to consider the contributions of each charge to the electric field at that point.
Charges +q are at points A and B, and charges -q are at points C and D.
The distance from each vertex to the intersection of the diagonals is calculated as (√2)/2 * L = L/√2.
The electric field due to a point charge q at a distance r is given by E = kq/r^2, where k is the Coulomb constant.
The electric field due to +q at A at the intersection of the diagonals is EA = 2kq/L^2, and its direction is along the diagonal AC.
The electric field due to +q at B at the intersection of the diagonals is EB = 2kq/L^2, and its direction is along the diagonal BD.
The electric field due to -q at C at the intersection of the diagonals is EC = -2kq/L^2, and its direction is opposite to the diagonal AC.
The electric field due to -q at D at the intersection of the diagonals is ED = -2kq/L^2, and its direction is opposite to the diagonal BD.
The electric field due to +q at A and B is in the same direction (along the diagonal AC and BD), so their vector sum is EAB = 4kq/L^2.
The electric field due to -q at C and D is in the opposite direction (opposite to the diagonal AC and BD), so their vector sum is ECD = -4kq/L^2.
The total electric field at the intersection of the diagonals is E_total = EAB + ECD = 4kq/L^2 - 4kq/L^2 = 0.
The electric field strength at the intersection of the diagonals of the square is 0.
